div.p: The two N-terminal domains (Dl-D2) of the infectivity protein g3p of Ff filamentous phages (M13, fd, fl) contain the binding sites for the two receptors of phage infection: the F'-pilus primary receptor as well as the TolA coreceptor. Recently, we have shown that during phage infection, the two receptors are contacted in a sequential manner, with binding site for TolA on the Dl domain blocked by the D2 domain in the absence of F'-pilus.
In order to better understand this process we have solved the crystal structure of the two N-terminal domains Dl-D2 of the infectivity protein g3p

figure.figDesc: of filamentous phage fd by a combination of MIR and molecular replacement phasing using data collected at ESRF's ID14-3 beamline. We collected data for a native crystal of a deletion variant of g3p consisting of the Dl and D2 domains, a crystal of a selenomethioninesubstituted DlD2, and a native crystal for a deletion variant consisting of Dl only. The crystals had unit cell a=125 A, b=78 A, c=63 A with symmetry P212121. The data were collected to 1.8 A, 2.5 A and 1.6 A for the DlD2, Se-Met DlD2 and Dl crystals, respectively. The structure of DlD2 was refined to 2.0 A with a free R-factor of 0.29. A schematic diagram of the DlD2 structure is illustrated in Fig. 1. While individual domains Dl and D2 superimpose well with the respective Dl and D2 domains in the g3p Dl-D2 structure from the related Ff phage M13, the two overall structures superimpose poorly. This is due to a 5 A movement of D2 with respect to Dl around a hinge located in a strand of a short anti-parallel betasheet that connects Dl to D2. The movement results in an opening up of a hydrophobic groove running between the two domains, postulated to contain the binding site for the F'-pilus. We propose a mechanism for the early steps of phage infection, whereby interaction with the pilus tip causes a conformational change that opens this groove and frees Dl for coreceptor binding.
